title: DS310.13 Term & Phrase Search | DataStax Enterprise 6 Search
description:
#DataStaxAcademy #DS310
DS310.13 Term & Phrase Search
In this section we will looking at performing searches using terms and phrases.

LEARN FOR FREE at https://academy.datastax.com -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.

ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.

transcript.text: [Music] in search there are terms and phrases where search queries can operate on either a phrase or a term searching for a term uses the following format field colon term where the field is the column you're searching in and the value or the term is what you're looking for this could be a text or it could be a number and it's driven by the type of field you designate there's special syntax that can be used to retrieve all the documents star colon star what this denotes is search for any value in any column looking at some examples if we want to retrieve all the documents we use this special notation we can also retrieve documents where the fields aren't null as well as searching for documents where a field matches a specific term an entire phrase can also be searched in a field this value must match the terms in the same order and double quotes will be needed to denote a phrase it's important to note that phrases and wild cards cannot be used in conjunction in the same query but you can search for multiple terms in a field use parentheses to make a grouping of terms this will turn documents that match any of these search terms searching for multiple fields can also be accomplished multiple fields can be searched using the same format field colon term these results will include rows that match any of the field term combinations boolean operations allow terms to be combined into unique and flexible conditional search expressions which can add to or limit the documents that get returned in the search results and you can further group these to further control the results you can make a term required by adding to the beginning of a term or phrase this will denote that the term is required to be in the document field on the search required term is processed regardless of other boolean operators similarly you can prohibit a term adding another notation to the beginning of the word or the term this will exclude documents that match this prohibited term the prohibited term is processed regardless of other boolean operators the not operator is similar to prohibit and will exclude documents that match the following term and of course you can enclose multiple terms within parentheses to create queries these groups can be chained with a boolean operator to expand the query and multiple terms can be grouped together without an operator which will default to the or boolean operator timestamps are also supported in your schema specifications and they follow a specific format the default time zone is utc and milliseconds are optional now let's try to put our newfound knowledge of terms phrases and forming cql search requests into action with an exercise [Music] you
